review_title: Make Them Tell You What You'll Be Paid For Every Year Of Your Assistantship
pros: Not many. Athens isn't bad when students leave for winter and summer breaks.
cons:
You will be paid an insultingly low wage as a graduate assistant at OU, regardless of department. I truly wish I had known this, as I had other options I would have pursued. 

We (a group of graduate students from across the university) had to petition the administration for more money and things like family leave and subsidized health insurance because graduate students at ALL of our peer institutions were making something approaching a livable wage except for those of us at OU. We did not get what we were asking for, and this why I cannot recommend anyone take a graduate assistantship at OU in any department for any school.

Please, please, PLEASE don't make the same mistake I did. Your department will try to play coy and hide this info from you. Don't let them. Get in writing what you will be making for every single year of your assistantship, because they will absolutely try to reel you in with a higher-sounding starting wage (it will still be lower than you'd get elsewhere), but they'll absolutely turn around and input your wages as less than ridiculous for subsequent years. Don't let this happen to you.

pros: Ohio University is a beautiful campus located on the Hocking River in Athens, Ohio. Its quaint setting and red-brick halls have earned the institution its nickname, "Harvard on the Hocking." Ohio has many great attributes, including wonderful students, caring and engaged faculty (both research and instructional), excellent graduate programs, and as already noted, a gorgeous setting.
cons: Executive leadership. Over the course of the last several years, the university's upper-level leadership (i.e., management and administration, not so much leadership) and its trustees have been in what can only be described as a tailspin. Due to trends (trends we have seen coming for years) in enrollment, the strategy has been a very reactive response to cut and burn programs and try to eliminate as many tenured faculty as possible. Instead of being responsive to the needs of the region and the critical programs that make Ohio University a unique and special institution of higher learning, it has elected to look only at the "bottom line." This has created an environment with much uncertainty and a climate marked by stress and anxiety for many.

job_title: Student Writing Center Tutor in Athens, OH
pros: **As a disclaimer - my experiences are based solely on working at the writing center during the remote era, and not the in-person tutoring at Athens. I am not sure if you can be employed by the main campus writing center post-remote, or if remote tutoring is still available at this time** Working as a writing tutor through OU was honestly a highlight of my college experience! I loved the stability of the work week-to-week, and the work environment was great (even due to the remote status of last semester). The remote aspect of this position also opened up this opportunity for me personally, since I attended a regional campus. You get paid for your assigned hours regardless if you actually work with a student during them, so sometimes you are basically paid for just being "available" during that time. I thoroughly enjoyed working with tutees from multiple majors on their papers, as this allowed me to learn about many different topics that I would not have been exposed to otherwise. Overall, I would highly recommend this job to any student who enjoys helping others with their writing - or who just want some extra funds to help them get through the semester!
cons: There honestly are not many cons about working as a writing tutor for OU, in my opinion. The work is pretty straight-forward, although you do not always know what stage of writing the tutee is at prior to the session. This is less of a fault of the university and more the tutee, since they have the option to describe what they are working on when they schedule the meeting (but often choose not to do so). Also, there isn't always work to be done, but you still have to be "available" during your hours if a tutee schedules a meeting last minute - which can be quite hectic. Again, this isn't truly a con because you get paid regardless of whether you complete sessions or not, but sometimes the uncertainty of whether you have to work with a tutee or not can be anxiety-inducing. Honestly, these "cons" do not outweigh the pros at all though, in my opinion!

pros: The university has a lot of very nice features. The campus is beautiful and the facilities range from historical to state-of-the-art. The uniformity and style of the halls, its location along the somewhat scenic Hocking River, as well as general reputation earn Ohio University the nickname Harvard on the Hocking.
cons: The administration is packed. Faculty can too often been treated as second class or unimportant. Heavy demands are placed on faculty—excessive emphasis on academic service and requirements to maintain a strong stream of inquiry without the time or other resources to do so. During the pandemic execs and admins became even more ruthless, taking bonuses and pay increases meanwhile making deep cuts to programs and lines of faculty. Leadership at the college levels can micromanage things that faculty should have an autonomous role in and yet remain laissez faire about things when they in fact should intervene.

review_title: Read the reviews from full-time administrators for a full picture
pros:
You will probably like the employees in your department, most are very good people. 

If you start working at OU straight from college, you might enjoy an extra year or more of living like a student while having a real, if small, paycheck.  

Beautiful campus, nice town, excellent recreation.
cons:
The other reviews on glassdoor are mostly accurate, with common themes that echo my own experiences - limited room for advancement, dysfunctional leadership, a caustic environment in finance, decisions by accounting, and passive-aggressive power struggles. Advancement often feels less like a competitive process and more like a beauty pageant. 

You will experience extreme resistance to change even though everyone knows that change is needed in other departments. Occasionally the place tries to change and brings in a new group of executives to do this. The new executives either stay stay for many years until finally asked to leave or move on after a couple years to a top-tier university. Don't expect much from new leadership.

Pay raises tend to match increases in the pay structure, so after spending years of experience learning to do your job really well, you will only earn slightly more than new employees with zero experience.

review_title: A state university that wants badly to be private
pros: State benefits, work-life balance (depends on the department). Ohio has one of the best pension programs in the country and the health insurance is pretty good. Work-life balance is good, depending on the department.
cons:
Rural location, campus politics, pay. 

You either love the location and culture, or hate it. I suggest you take a hard look at what's around and be honest with yourself about it. OU and Athens is not for everyone. The student culture is questionable at times, and the non-OU locals aren't too keen on OU folks. It can be lonely at times. Also, a car is mandatory. 

Everything is political. The most simple tasks become bogged down by backstories and politics. 

As I mentioned above, some departments take work-life balance seriously. Others do not and expect you to be tied to your phone or email at all times. It's understandable for those mid to upper level administrators who get paid to be available, but for the average administrator, it's unfair and unrealistic. 

OU will keep employees that aren't up to standards, but move them around laterally. So it's musical chairs with lackluster employees.

pros: Beautiful campus to work on
cons: Salary is so very low

review_title: Too many cooks in the kitchen.
pros: A lot of time off, very generous benefits package including 403(b) contributions, very good health care benefits.  Laid-back culture typical of higher ed.
cons: Very low salaries for technical personnel compared even with other public universities: they have a tiered pay structure, but always only pay the minimum for that tier, irrespective of experience.  Too many cooks in the kitchen: middle leadership is often at odds with one another making contradictory policies for dealing with other units.  Cliquey subcultures where people are given preferential treatment or excluded depending on their affiliation or lack thereof.  Decisions are made at a very high level without a good understanding of the situation on the ground.

review_title: If you're in this town, you don't have any other real employment options, and the university treats you accordingly.
pros: It's a paycheck--that's the best that I can say.
cons: I'm currently working in a position that is far, far below my skill level, and I was informed at the interview that there will be no advancement--a dead end from day one. The best that you can hope for is to jump to another department. After more than ten years here (my spouse is a tenured professor) in two different positions, I have seen no signs of change. Except at the executive level (or in the athletic department), compensation and benefits are mediocre. The local environment, both physical and cultural, is dismal, and the prospects for change are slim to none. Columbus is an hour and a half away; that's a long round trip to access a third-tier provincial city.

review_title: Great for corporate experience, but management has issues
job_title: Event Support Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: Easily the best part time job I've worked. As a full time student OUES is willing to work around your schedule and classes. Pay is adequate and what you would expect for a part time collegr job. Pay raises every two semesters is a good reason to stick around. Culture is fun and co workers are great. Job is relatively easy as well, and there's a good culture of getting work done.
cons: Management can be simultaneously overbearing and non present at the same time. Scheduled are supposed to be published two weeks in advance and hardly are. There's lots of useless micromanaging that could be done away with. Some managers can be anal about certain events (good for the driven but for the rest of employees it's just a paycheck) Training is mismanaged to the point of being broken, but promotions are possible for the really driven.

review_title: Every man for himself. Unless you are in the Dean's Office.
pros: Great location, plenty of parking now that students are dropping out. Some people get paid to take long walks up & down the hill and across campus.  Night classes are being eliminated so parking is available even more than in the daytime.
cons: Management has no clue they are ruining the school.  High absence rate.  Low morale.  Very little teamwork.  Different answers from different departments.  No one is ever in the Dean's Office.  The dean is never available and the associate dean goes on trips every month to promote her book.  Nickel and dime attitude.

review_title: Entrusted with a lot of autonomous responsibility
pros: Very good senior management in my department in terms of communication, leadership, and encouraging development. Very strong team concept among the employees. Many employees in admissions are not far-removed from finishing college but they are still expected to proactively rise to the challenge of making decisions that ultimately affect and represent the university at large. Department preferred to hire and promote from within whenever possible. Excellent paid time off options.
cons: Compensation isn't much to brag about, but that is the case anywhere in admissions. There is not really a clear path to promotion as you might find in sales positions, for example. You have to wait for positions above you to open up which may be few and far between.

pros: I have worked at Alden Library for 4 years now, and this has been one of the most informative and fun work experiences I have ever had.  My student supervisor is the best and really easy to get along with, and it is so clear to everyone that he has all of his students' best interests in mind.  The work hours are flexible, and school always comes first so you never have to worry about missing something class-related because of work.  Many of the other librarians and on-desk staff are great people too, and overall it's a very relaxed work atmosphere.  There's opportunities for growth and always something new to learn!
cons: The only downside is that it can be difficult to get a lot of hours, but this is only a part-time job and the supervisor definitely tries his hardest to get his students as many hours as they can manage.

pros: It is easy to work with and befriend the other admissions employees. Athens is a lovely town, but it is somewhere you should live for four years or for your entire life. There is a lot to do in Athens, even if you are not a student.
cons: Most of the employees are either new, young and only going to be there for a few years or are much older and have worked there for a long time. This makes for a very pronounced separation. The different departments do not speak to each other very well. Lots of bureaucracy (although that is typical in a university setting).

review_title: I feel bad for incoming residential housing professionals.
pros: Department heads are working on trying to turn things around, but some are VERY steadfast in their attempts to keep the status quo. They've brought a lot of really great people onboard and in time there just might be hope. Close community. Some of the higher ups in the department really want to see you succeed and others have too much on their plate to care who you are or what you're doing (until it affects them).
cons: Politics. SO much departmentalization. If you're lower on the totem pole, don't expect to bring about any change. Experiences really vary by building though. I didn't feel very supported by other university departments or the heads of my own department.

review_title: Information Technology Has Gone Down The Tubes
pros: Athens is beautiful.  The Ohio campus is beautiful.  There are many, many great people there.  It has traditionally been a truly wonderful place to work.
cons: The IT department has become caustic.  Ever since the current CIO arrived, everyone is on egg shells and constantly looking over their shoulder.  Nobody trusts upper management who struts around like Little Lord Farqaad saying one thing and demonstrating another.  Everyone there used to live for that department.  Now, almost everyone I know hates it there.  I know many people looking for new positions and greener pastures.  With everyone they have been letting go and running off, it seems they only want Jr experience (and the cheaper labor) that goes with them.

pros:
- Employees and their families receive discounted/free (undergraduate) tuition
- Work hours somewhat flexible
- Passionate students and alumni base
cons: The supervisor of our team is incredibly toxic and our college will not reprimand this person. Other employees within our college are discouraged from talking to us. Poor leadership sets a bad example for both new hires and more importantly student employees who observe how their money is wasted in our dysfunctional office. Our student employees are overworked, yet not provided meaningful experience. There is a severe culture of blame where no one takes ownership for mistakes and points fingers rather than problem solving.

pros: I love the people.  Great attitude all around, top to bottom.  As a college student, flexibility is of the utmost importance.  With such a large pool of employees, it is VERY rare that I cannot get a shift covered if I need to.  They work around my class schedule and as long as I give 3 weeks notice, any time-off request is approved 99% of the time.
cons: Occasional last minute scheduling, but impossible to avoid due to the dynamic nature of hosting events.  Occasional late night setup shifts that are for only 1 to 2 hours.. which are annoying but again, impossible to avoid.

pros:
Easy going
Supportive environment 
Town the university is in.. is wonderful
Perfect for a laid back individual running from city city life
Little can beat the experience of living and working in the idyllic town of Athens
cons:
Pay isn't that good, especially if you're a student work
The town is suited only for laid back individuals; if you're an ambitious person with a zest for fast-paced life, OU or Athens isn't for you
OU, ultimately, is a below mid-level, rural Appalachia university - expectations of both awesomeness of the place and its downsides need to be bounded strictly within the previously mentioned consideration

pros:
Good research benefits (research incentive)
Flexible hours
Supportive administration
Decent health benefits, great "trailing spouse" program to help your spouse find a job within the university (must be married, currently doesn't support civil unions).
cons: Athens is a smaller town. If you are more of a city person, you will not be happy in Athens. OU occasionally has issues in determining if it wants to be a research centric university, or a teaching university. As a result you may get mixed messages in terms of the importance of research.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Athens, OH
pros: Great benefits! 22 vacation days a year, flexible scheduling in the summer, plenty of growth opportunities in departments across the University, fun place to work. Each department is different but many have professional development funds to send their employees to trainings and conferences, which is always a fun time.
cons: Lots of politics and hoops to jump through to get anything done. It can easily take 3 months to apply and get hired on in a position. Because it's such a large university, lots of people have opinions and everything needs approved by upper management (which is also a lot of people) so things take a while to get done.

pros:
Working in higher ed, there is a unique pride associated with the college sports teams, which makes for an exciting environment.
There are loads of multi-cultural events on campus, and diversity/inclusion is a stronghold of the University.
Many opportunities for professional development and career paths.
cons:
As a state school, funding from state and federal governments have a huge impact on our lives. Depending on the political climate, we may have more or less money in a given year, and it's usually an unknown during election cycles. Raises can be hard to come by, even cost of living. Jobs could be eliminated, though in that case, they really try to find another place for you within the University.

Work environment and culture vary widely between colleges and departments.

job_title: Food Production Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: As this is just a college job, it's nice that everyone you work with is in the same situation.  They are understanding of class/activity conflicts and let you schedule around them.
cons: It's a low paying job but that's to be expected.  Most other student employees you work with do not care about the job or treat it as a "real" job.  Super high turnover.

pros: Great benefits and low cost of living.
cons: Poor management and direction of the University.  Things seem to be very unstable and upper management is very out of touch with what is going on ground level.  There has been so many cuts with regular staff and then they wonder why things are not getting done, but upper management has been hired in record numbers with very high wages, but student population is at the highest ever!  Every department doing more with less, therefore morale is low and stress is high!

pros: OU is a lovely campus in a picturesque location.  Overall, the administrators are given a good amount of autonomy and freedom in their research interests - within reason. Rural Ohio in the foothills of the Appalachians is a lovely setting in which to raise a family.
cons: Primarily known as a "party school" - weekends start on Wednesday night for most of the students.  Tight salaries and even tighter working budgets.  Expect to pay out of pocket for any and all off campus professional development.  Heavy turnover.  People don't tend to stay here.

review_title: Work is great, but the budget cuts arn't/
pros: Great Culture. There are so many aspects to Ohio University. You will never be bored. The people who work there are usually great to work with. Some arn't as good as others. There are many different departments and positions that you can move up in. Benefits are pretty good. They offer free tuition for you and to your immediate family.
cons: Budget Cuts have been a large factor to the problem. It is hard to get new equipment approved. Hiring freezes have gone into affect and puts some departments in a pinch.

review_title: EE Satisfaction varies a great deal
pros: College campus, lots of hills, trees.  while several buildings are reasonable, fiscal mis-management has meant that many are in disrepair, and need a lot of maintenance just to keep them usable.
cons: Upper  Management is very much a "in" or "out" group.  In some areas all HR rules about hiring and promoting are completely ignored if you are "in" with the right people.  Many are frustrated with those in upper management (below the President) and OU is losing a lot of good people.

pros: Working for Ohio University as a student allowed me to gain experience in my field while funding my education. The University is on pace to grow rapidly over the coming years.
cons: WellWorks could use some upgrades. The equipment is outdated and some of it should have been replaced years ago. Although the student employees do their best to keep equipment clean, some of it is old and grimy.

pros: Some people are nice, but they usually quit due to idiotic management.  University benefits are nice, but dealing with the people doesn't make it worth it.
cons: If you graduated from the University or already work in the department and apply for any position, you will get it automatically. This leads to the wrong people getting a job they aren't qualified for. Which leads to terrible management, unhappy workers and a high turnover rate. Upper management refuses to believe there's a problem and if you don't kiss any upper management butt, you're screwed.  Just stay away from Undergraduate Admissions in general. Only complete idiots are promoted.

pros:
Great customer service experience
Friendly colleagues

I have worked here for years under different job titles, and the atmosphere here is awesome.  If the pay were better, this would be the perfect job.
cons:
Terrible pay
No benefits
Not much work/life balance

Not a bad place to work for by any means, but I can barely survive on what I get paid.  If I get sick or injured, I have absolutely no recourse because I don't get paid enough to afford health (or any other) insurance.  Because my shift is in the afternoon to late evening, I barely ever have free time that I don't use to sleep.

pros: The financial aid is a good option to help you go through your studies. The university is very diverse and you get to learn a lot from other cultures.
cons: No benefits and you have to purchase the university insurance which is very bad. It doesn't cover much and has a lot of out pocket expenses. Your work load depends on the professor you are assisting. Some professors are generous and understand you are also a graduate student. Others don't and they want you to do much of their own work.

pros: The TA'ship is a great opportunity to get a salary to pay for some bills while studying a graduate program.
cons: Sadly as in many graduate programs in the country, for many TA's their salary is not enough. Ohio University has some (hidden) fees that you have to pay back while being a graduate student. These fees cost around $500 a month and they eats a good chunk of your salary.

review_title: At times enjoyable, but often extremely bureaucratic.
pros: Great school and a beautiful campus. Compensation package helps to slightly ease living expenses. Opportunities for leadership and staff development are plentiful. Additionally, opportunities with other campus organizations are present.
cons: Having to cope with the "party culture" of Ohio University. One gets the sense that many resident directors and assistants put on an air of "cheerleader" that comes across as extremely contrived. The compensation package as compared to comparable schools is abominable. Many of the higher-ups tout a "well, I'm the boss" attitude. The feeling of expendability and vulnerability in one's job occurs quickly.

pros: Cannot think of many "pros".
cons: Management is very unrealistic.  I have worked for three other universities and they were all fair in their expectations.  In addition, I was injured at work and they immediately started battling against me by contesting every allowance that bureau of workers compensation allowed.  I even had witnesses and was treated at the O'Bleness ER to which I was taken by an EMT team.  One would think that they would want to get a hard working employee healthy and back to work but this is not the case at Ohio University.  They just sick their attorneys on the injured worker and hope they will go away.

pros: Quality of the people, small town atmosphere, pretty campus and surrounding area. Good place to live with a family of school-aged kids.
cons: Senior leadership does not have a strong vision for the institution, and there has been a great deal of turnover in leadership positions, particularly on the administrative side. The decentralized control (decision-making authority given to academic units) makes the institution inefficient. Interdisciplinary cooperation is challenging, and institutional support for central academic functions (teaching and learning, academic technologies, etc.) is almost nonexistent.

review_title: Graduate assistant working in the environmental studies program
pros: I've had the benefit of working on projects that introduced me to a whole slew of new contacts in the Washington, D.C. policy world, thanks to my advisor Dr. Geoff Dabelko. I also assisted in developing a study abroad program and writing grants for various projects happening within the school. Really a great place to gain vital real-world skills.
cons: There are only four full-time faculty members for the environmental studies program so individualized attention is a bit hard to come by--requires you to be a real self-starter. Depending on yourself is fine until you actually need some detailed feedback on a project or, say, your thesis.

review_title: Great university, be cautious of middle management.
pros: Ohio University is a classic, iconic campus. Brick walkways, tree-lined campus, an infectious environment and great students. People who go to school at Ohio University frequently stay in the area to work or start a business. The benefits at the university are excellent, with free tuition for employees and children. They truly believe in diversity, which frankly is a bit difficult to find on campus, since there is not a great diverse employee base in SE Ohio. The student population however is very diverse and engaging.
cons:
Be very cautious about Term Class 3 employment status. These position are strict contract with no benefits - no medical and no employee protection. You are enrolled in the Ohio state retirement system, but Class 3 employees are underpaid in comparison to comparable full-time staff work. If you are promised a temporary Term 3 position with the promise of a full-time staff posting, get such agreements in writing. Don't believe verbal commitments.

Faculty is generally fantastic. The administrative side of the house is very variable. You can be in a wonderful, engaging environment with a fantastic supervisor or you can be in a manipulative pit with a supervisor who cannot be trusted. Try to find someone in your area you can talk to to find out what the environment is like before you commit.

review_title: Dedicated people, but a lot of bureaucracy
pros: The people who work here are by and large wonderful. Ohio University is a great place to establish and grow a long-term career. You're encouraged and supported to continue to grow your career and seek out new opportunities within the large university.
cons: Like any large, older organization, there is a lot of bureaucracy to contend with. People want to make changes, but sometimes it can take a while and be unwieldy.

pros: Wonderful campus. Everyone is very friendly there, even in the parking services office. As a student worker, your schedule is worked around to the best of their ability and they really make you feel like you are being utilized to your full potential.
cons: Management is not always they best. Especially in the parking department. Managers get to take vacation whenever they want and leave students to clean up the messes with customers that were left behind.

pros: I worked for a year as a part-time instructor at Ohio University. A very positive experience with the students and the academic departments don't treat their instructors/adjuncts as complete second class citizens. Though depending on the department there may be minor to major amounts of politics and favoritism that goes on.
cons: Old can sometimes be charming at a University, but not so much at many of the buildings on campus. Many have been left to deteriorate, as have the classrooms. Also the location of Athens Ohio is not the greatest, but may be worth it for some to work at this University.

review_title: Be flexible and find the value in it
job_title: Assistant Resident Director in Athens, OH
pros:
- Gaining experience at a large public institution
- Great college environment to grow in
- Learning to work with a wide spectrum of personality types
- Learning to work with anyone from a student to a department head on any given day
- Helps strengthen a multitasking, self-starter and creative thinking skills
cons:
- Can be disorganized at times
- Not every supervisor upholds departmental policy the same; therefore, not everyone in this position will hold the same repetitive responsibilities
- Students can go through serious or traumatic experiences and you are expected to always be capable of helping. This can be challenging sometimes

review_title: If you have actual experience without an advanced degree, you will go nowhere in this position.
pros: If you are looking for work/life balance this is the place for you. If you are seeking employment as a professor or faculty member, this is the place for you.  If you are one of the very fortunate few to be sought out by a headhunting firm for a place in upper administration or as the football coach, this is the place for you and as upper management or football coach you will be well paid and live in SE Ohio and enjoy very low cost of living. Athens Ohio is a WONDERFUL place to live and raise a family.  It is open friendly and a great community.
cons: You will never get a raise. They don't exist. If you have a bachelors degree or less and are career oriented, you will go nowhere in any coordinator or other similar positions at the university.  You can be knowledgeable and productive until you are blue in the face. Promotions are only given to those with Master's degrees and Ph.Ds.  Middle and upper managers are generally former scholars and in such they are very knowledgeable in only one area and that area is almost always not management. You will often be embarrassed by utter lack of domain knowledge held by assumed "knowledgeable" managers who achieved their position via the proper piece of paper as opposed to any proven results in previous positions. If you have worked in government, you will find this to be a familiar environment. The higher people go, the less accountable they become and the less they have any real practical experience in the domain that they are "managing" I watched a director stand in the hall and complain for 7 hours/day for years before finally retiring. Good for them, bad for their demoralized employees.

review_title: Most of the time it was stressful, but you were able to work around your own class schedule which was nice.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: Gained a lot of labwork experience and was able to get published for several journal articles. Also became familiar with many standard laboratory techniques.
cons: There was not a lot of direction, most of the work was up to you to figure out. Most weeks you worked well over the 20 hour work week as a grad assistant to get all of the research done. It also would have been helpful if there was newer equipment to have better results with some of the research.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, OH
pros:
People are friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable and will support you in your education and development.
Employees are easy to reach and quickly respond to emails.
The school is located in Athens, which is beautiful and has lots of opportunities for outdoor recreation.
cons:
Athens is a relatively small town so it might take some getting used to if you are accustomed to a big city.
Graduate assistants have to pay a relatively large general fee and do not get much subsidy for health insurance.

pros: The pros is this beautiful campus and the community of Athens.  There is a lot to do for outdoor enthusiasts, and for folks who love a college town vibe.
cons:
This is the epitome of silo leadership.  Each college and office on campus works within itself, rarely and reluctantly sharing information to the outside.  The President is a fraud, and one of the more unfriendly people on the entire staff.  He is leaving because he has been caught lying in scheme to buy a house from an unscrupulous business man, one who gives generously to the university in return for favors.  He is currently under investigation, as are other top administrators, by the Ohio Attorney General.  He is not an accountable person so he's passing the proverbial buck on to the others.  
Pay here is every uneven, and the pay of every employee is available to anyone on the 2nd floor of Alden Library.  Pay inequity is huge, and they tried to curtain this in 2014 but very little has changed.  HR often turns a blind eye to hiring practices, especially when desired candidates do not have the proper credentials for the job.  This happens on every level, and because the HR Department is so dysfunctional, nothing is done and turn over there is extremely high.  
It's still very much a "good ole boys" network here, and if that disgusts you, it should.  During the RIF's of 2010 and 2011, 95% of those released from duty were women...long serving, powerful women.  One woman in particular was asked in her capacity as University Spokesperson, to help the HR Department formulate the communication plan for the Reduction in Force, only to receive the final pink slip in a meeting with the boss not human enough to let he know it was coming.  Yes, this happened, and devastated her.  She was essentially ordered to dig her own grave.  
Good luck on your search.

review_title: Fun place to work.  I love to interact with the faculty, staff and students.
pros: The amazing amount of people that I get to network with is irreplaceable.  I have gotten to see many sides of business.
cons: Very random hours for my job.  There are times you are exposed to extreme heat.

pros: It's good to have a job at all in southeast Ohio, where full-time employment is becoming something of a rarity. The pay isn't bad, given the locality, even if it lags behind rates in more civilized regions.
cons: It's a very small pond, and you spend a lot of time swimming in circles. Some people like circles, and they tend to be satisfied with working at Ohio University. Others, not so much.

pros:
Athens is a wonderful small town. There are a tremendous amount of resources across the campus and thankfully most people are willing to work to help each other.

Good lesson is to keep a low-profile and work through back channels if you want to accomplish things.
cons: It is a larger university so there is a decent amount of bureaucracy. There are times when people would be willing or like to collaborate but there is just too much red tape to do so.

pros: My particular job has a great deal of flexibility of hours which has allowed me to drop off or pick up my son at school. The educational benefit is a very good deal.
cons: That same flexibility leads to unpredictability I do not know when I will have to work late and early.The lab is small and independent so there is no opportunity to advance. Senior administration has routinely interfered with raises when our lab had grant money for them.

review_title: Regional Campuses Matter instead of Responsibility Centered Management (RCM)
pros:
This campus was an amazing campus to work at in the late 1990's & early 2010's.  The buildings mimic Athens, but the culture does not.  Regional campuses are slowly being squeezing financially to support a new budget model & centralization in Athens.  
If you ever watched the movie dumb & dumber...send the guys to apply to OU as a liaison.  Make sure they go to the Main campus, though.  Regional campuses just need paper pushers.  They can't make decisions because they are misrepresented.
cons: Morale is so low most people don't even bother to show up or spend more time trying to get off work.  Many of us resigned or retired, but RHE will not allow positions to be filled. Administrators who ran the campus for 10+ years have to ask permission to post a job, hire a contractor, or pay a bill.  It's humiliating. Faculty travel has all but been taken away.  No mileage, maybe 1 PD conference a year.  How do we learn new topics? The campus saves money, but the students lose.  Also-students are being charged fees for career counseling & the person their fees are paying to support hasn't even been hired.  Just not good business for any campus.  Other places would call it payment for nonservice.  Is that even legal?

pros: good co workers, creative environment. All in all the place has decent ethics.  I think some staff and faculty get frustrated because it's not a socialist utopia they dream they deserve. they forget how conservative the real world is and get greedy there.
cons: low expectations of some faculty- they can suck and no one cares. Generally a good place, the bad apples are the exception

review_title: Not the greatest place to work.
pros: Beautiful natural areas around Athens, some talented and dedicated staff, and a relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Pay is lower than other universities in Ohio. In my department (College of Fine Arts) the staff doesn't get along and passive-aggressive power struggles are common. University wide priorities are expanding enrollment and athletics/student recreation, not academics and certainly not fine arts.

pros: Free housing, single dorm room. The opportunity to meet lots of new people. Great opportunities to work in teams and develop yourself. The experience looks good on a resume and got me my next job.
cons: Dealing with rowdy college students, strict work schedule, very little flexibility to leave campus when you want to. Did I mention rowdy college students?

pros: Competitive pay considering the area, but very low pay when consideration of equal positions at other Universities.
cons: Little support from leadership team who do not care to know what the "little people" need or feel.  It's all about the all-mighty dollar in the end.  No loyalty to employees, and their HR department is in place to protect OU not employees.

pros: Fun coworkers and a flexible schedule. Paid breaks, excluding lunch, and everyone got their hand at managing people. Very dynamic work groups.
cons: The pay was a joke. Management was paranoid about everything. There were new rules every day and often times the rules would limit our ability to do our work.

pros: Overall is a great university.  Everyone here is treated well and Athens is a wonderful college town with tons to do.
cons: Sometimes the party atmosphere can be a bit much.  Students value getting drunk to the point where some people go to the bars 3-4 times a week and it seems like that is all people ever want to do.

pros: OU has a beautiful campus located in scenic southeast Ohio. The work the university does educating undergraduates who otherwise might not go to college is ultimately very needed in the area.
cons: The University relies heavily on hiring alumni without considering who best in the field could best fill spots leading to departments or whole schools without new knowledge or viewpoints coming through the door.

pros: I don't have much work to do, so it allows me to focus more on my class work and interviews.
cons: Zero practical experience I can apply to my career moving forward. Boss has very little contact with me and is extremely aloof. Stipend is nothing to write home about nor is the tuition waiver.

pros: Excellent work experience, real work unlike some other student jobs. This job requires a degree of fortitude in order to hold together
cons: There is a pretty significant level of disorganization going on here which I think makes it difficult for the student-workers to have faith in the organization as a whole

pros: The community and town is so great! I really wish I could stay
cons:
The Leadership Team is lost and uninformed, yet they feel they must be included in every decision that passes through the department. This causes their employees to feel unappreciated, underutilized, and not trusted to do their jobs.

Expectations are impossible to reach and are constantly moving, deadlines are dropped due to poor planning and management, and everyone is always looking over their shoulders wondering how much longer they have left to work here before they are replaced by a lower paying job.

pros: Ohio University is a rare institution that values high quality research as well as training of students. Teaching is valued across the university at the undergraduate and graduate levels.
cons: The tenure system allows some faculty to stay who would better serve the department by leaving or retiring, but this is true of any academic institution. At times, the grant and financial aspects of doing research at Ohio University were confusing and it was difficult to find the appropriate staff member to help.

pros: Beautiful campus and nearby natural area. Environmentally and socially engaged local community. The university still has some excellent faculty and programs, but it is nothing compared to what this school once offered.
cons: Unfortunately the increasing business-like climate and culture of mediocrity are undermining what was once an excellent university. There appears to be no focus on education among the myopic administrators who are squandering what remains of this fine old institution. Politics, infighting and bullying seem to be standards operating procedures. There is little concern about faculty and students, unless they are football players, that is.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Athens, OH
pros: This is an excellent location to work in . It is a university town with great character and great people. Lots of outdoor activities.
cons: There are really no major downsides except if you are person who prefers a more urban work location. This University is poised for some great things.

pros: It was the people that I worked with that made going to work fun and livable. Better time off with family and children.
cons: Behind in technology, making changes seemingly every year to operations and management. Seems like they keep trying to change things around in the university to make it more effective or cost saving and it can make work a hassle.

review_title: GA for the Physical and Wellness program at Ohio University
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: Free Tuition and direct deposit paychecks twice a month.
cons: Does not cover student fees such as health insurance, student legal services, etc.

pros: Full time employees get really great health benefits for themselves and spouses and dependents and 2 vacation days/month starts immediately. Plus sick days.
cons: Everything is bureaucratic. Heads of departments don't really help you out with anything. Purchasing orders or getting reimbursed is really complicated. The whole of Athens is a college town.

pros: Ohio University provides a great working climate in a small town setting.  The students are relaxed but engaged.
cons: While it is a great school, there is a lack of opportunity for advancement beyond the position for which you were hired.  Major raises only come from moving to new positions.

review_title: In Transition - the finances of this place are a mess.
pros: Low cost of living, summers off, pay is competitive, low stress, good benefits, stable job if you can get tenure, people are friendly, easy-to-manage, small town environment.
cons: Isolated, poorly managed, budget troubles, poor leadership and communications, unclear direction, layoffs on the horizon. Good people leave and it seems people who should be demoted get promoted.  Seems like many, many people are leaving.

pros: Great people eager to help you succeed. They know a lot about their field and are passionate about what they do.
cons: The very same people are annoying though and they are not consistent. They are a bit racist too if I may be frank and this school is not the place for students of a different race.

review_title: Good for student employment, but aim for titles and recommendations, not portfolio material.
pros: A lot of unique opportunities relevant to various fields if you're willing to dig for them. Almost all departments are flexible in scheduling for students. Generally laid back working environment.
cons: Departments are very segmented and are often too concerned with getting their own piece. Little unifying leadership on key topics: marketing/promotion, overall vision, etc.

review_title: Fun but like many colleges there is too much overhead and little return on investment
pros: beautiful, great atmosphere and great people. I particular like the hiking nearby and the many opportunities around campus to be involved.
cons: Administration seems to not listen to its students, and transparency is very poor. There also is a lack of efficiency in how the University is run.

job_title: Assistant Resident Director in Athens, OH
pros: The Residential Life and Housing department is a great department to work for. They are always striving to become better for RAs and for the residents as well.
cons: This position is new and not all of the kinks are worked out yet. The job looks very different depending on the Residence Hall you work in.

review_title: Be careful when trying to complete your thesis or dissertation!
pros: Good education, good real-world learning experiences as Research Assistant
cons: The research is typically expected to help you complete your thesis/dissertation. Be careful here, as your advisor may set you on a path that will result in never completing your degree!

pros: Great people to work with
cons:
Managers under way too much pressure to minimize cost and reduce employees
Extremely stressful job to have on top of being a full time student this is not for the faint of heart.

pros: Work/Life balance. My staff/RD were incredible, and it was great working with them.
cons: Too much busy work. Spend such a focus on getting kids in trouble instead of letting them grow and learn through experience. 8pm rounds are a waste of time. Depending on your staff and RD, you could have a great time or a terrible time.

review_title: Quirky, but a steady check with benefits
pros:
Benefits are nice, and reasonably priced
100% tuition discount for employee and dependents
cons:
Micromanaging by people who don't always understand how the position works
Lack of quality communication between superiors/employees

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: The GTA position paid for all of my living expenses and tuition for grad school. It was a lot of work, but I definitely benefited for the teaching experience and got through my Masters debt-free!
cons: There really isn't any- you're a grad student so you are expected to work hard and long days. Sometimes I would be thrown into substituting a class without any prior notice so that could get a little stressful.

pros: I'm sure it varies by department, but my responsibilities as a TA were pretty balanced with my student / life responsibilities. The support staff in our department were great. The stipend was favorable compared to similar schools.
cons: Not a good place to find a romantic partner. Hard for both in a couple moving here to find work. Considering the size of the town there's a lot to do but it is isolated.

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Clairsville, OH
pros: Great for students who find a professor working on research that aligns with their interests and can lead to some type of work in their field once they graduate.
cons: Very hard to get a position. Most positions are designed for a specific person and have limited hours.

job_title: Alden Library Support Associate in Athens, OH
pros: great benefits, awesome co-workers, the best place a person could work if they are in the Southeast Ohio region
cons: greedy administration and not always support to the library coming from the very top. this is a problem with must public universities though

pros:
Doing researches while you are pursuing your Ph.D degree
Chance to join a large collaboration to get data from top facilities and gain more experience
Good work/life balance
Good recreational facilities
Quiet place to concentrate on researches
Nice people in Athens
cons:
Relatively less career opportunites, especially in the industry
Not all faculties are active or have the expected capabilities
A disappointing president
Bureaucratic university management

review_title: Education is over. It ended here.
pros: Beautiful in spring. Nice campus.
cons: The list of cons is long. Gray in winter. No room for growth. Terrible leadership. Just do a find for "vision ohio" and you'll get an idea of how bereft of ideas and, ironically, vision this place is. That document took some of the brightest minds at Ohio to put together. Those with truly bright minds -- there are a couple -- are constantly fighting the good fight against an obtuse administration that does not understand education. Middle and upper management is overpaid.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: Flexible, Less workload and had enough time to study at least one course every semester. Depends on the professor you work with.
cons: Not many choices to select in term of different fields. Funding might not be regular, volatile but one will be supported by teaching assistantship. Health Insurance is very high.

pros: this is a great place to start. lots of opportunities and facilities. nice people and constant encouragement. nice library system.
cons: crowded. need to have good time management skills to get things done. talk to senior for help and wait for appointments to get thru.

pros:
* Good people
* Nice work environment
* You will fall in love with Athens for sure!
cons: Not a city, it is a town. So, If you are more into city life Athens can give you some but not many options as in a city. About OU, I have no complaints. It has been really good to be (I credit that to my boss for sure.)

pros: Pretty campus despite the deferred maintenance black hole that threatens it.
cons:
I am told that there are huge differences between the admin and academic sides of the University. This is an opinion on working as a experienced professional, not a student.  

The Finance and Administration (VPFA) side of OU may be the most caustic professional environment you will ever experience in your life.  From the top of it down to its directors and supervisors, with very few exceptions, the in-fighting, lack of trust and overbearing personalities combine to create an astonishingly dysfunctional business unit.

review_title: I was satisfied with the position and my responsibilities.
job_title: Head Graduate Assistant in Athens, OH
pros: Great bosses, many GA positions available, working in teams, not micromanaged.
cons: When working outside of scheduled GA hours, pay was terrible.  Repetition at times.

pros: Good work life balance. Nice community. We had very good experience with the local school. The Office of Research had very nice personable people as well as HR.
cons: School struggles recruiting talented graduate students. The culture for postdoctoral mentoring is nascent. A postdoc is seen as a grad student instead of a prefaculty. Had to share office with undergrads.

pros: Gave me invaluable experience in procedural techniques, chemical procedures, and proper use of PPEs. Allowed me more time in the laboratory for my class requirements and to help other students achieve success in their classes.
cons: Laboratory was small and only allowed for a small number of students to work at one time. Some equipment was out-of-date.

pros: Great town and environment for families. Some great, committed colleagues, great academic programs
